Table of Contents

Name

rvstack - extract Radius-Velocity diagram from a data cube for later

stacking

Synopsis

rvstack in=cube out=map [parameter=value]

Description

rvstack takes all points within a (narrow) wedge around the major or minor axis of an assumed galaxy disk data cube, and construct a Radius-Velocity diagram, centered on the galaxy in position and velocity. It will stack the two sides of the galaxy (but see also side=), so the radial coordinate will run from 0 to some Rmax. In velocity it will run from some Vmin to some Vmax, but always expecting positive rotation and positive outflow, assuming the position angle is correctly set.

Weak signal rotation and/or bulk outflow could be detected this way, but we offer no guarentee. If you have many like-minded galaxies, stacking these images may beat the noise down much more.

Options exist to scale the Radius and Velocity to different units, such that many galaxies can be stacked in physical space, as opposed to angular space. See rscale= and vscale=.

When gscale=t is set, the coordinates are scaled as follows: 

Rotation    Outflow
--------    -------
R        R/cos(i)
V/sin(i)    V/cos(i)
this will likely leave some gaps in radius and velocity. See discussion below.

You can also select to only construct the signal from one side of the galaxy. See side= below.

Points along an arc are all accumulated (technically: averaged), and placed on the same radial grid as the pixel size in the input data cube. We might need some trick next neighbor smoothing in order for pixels near the center to have a value.

Parameters

The following parameters are recognized in order; they may be given in any order if the keyword is also given. Use --help to confirm this man page is up to date.
in=image_cube
input data cube, in standard image(5NEMO) format. [No default]
out=image_map
output R-V map. [No default]
pa=
position angle along which the wedge is taken. This is normally the receding side (with mode=rotation) or the minor axis near side (for mode=outflow), in order get a positive velocity signal in the RV map. Only when gscale=t is set, will there be a difference how the radius and velocity are scaled.
inc=
inclination angle of the disk [45]
vsys=
systemic velocity [0]
center=xpos,ypos
rotation center (0,0=lower left). If not supplied, the reference pixel will be used. Default: reference pixel.
angle=
angle around major or minor axis around which points are accumulated into the R-V plot. [Default: 10]
blank=
Value of the blank pixel to be ignored. Not yet used.
rscale=
Scaling factor for radius. This would be used to stack galaxies based on a KPC scaling, or an Re scaling, not geometry, see gscale= below. [Default: 1]
vscale=
Scaling factor for velocity. This would be used to stack galaxies based on a mass scaling, not geometry, see gscale= below. [Default: 1]
gscale=f|t
Scale for inclination based geometry. Rotation is scaled by 1/sin(i), outflow by 1/cos(i). Radius is not scaled for rotation, but by 1/cos(i) for outflow. [Default: f]
mode=r|o
Select output mode: rotation (r) or outflow (o) . For rotation, points around pa= are selected, for outflow, points around pan=. [Default: r]
side=0|-1|1
By default it will stack both sides, but this option will allow you to stack one or the other side. [Default: 0]

Caveats

No geometric correction is made based on the angle in the disk. This could become a future option

A wedge has the disadvantage the the noise decreases inversely proportional to the sqrt(radius)

The gaps in radius and/or velocity produced with gscale=t can be a nuisance. For stacking many images, this should disappear, but otherwise some smoothing/interpolation might be needed. Not implemented.

Examples

An example using our standard NGC 6503 cube given in km/s velocity units. 


  rvstack ngc6503.ccd rvma.ccd pa=-60 inc=75 vsys=27 center=164,123 rscale=3600

  rvstack ngc6503.ccd rvmi.ccd pa=30  inc=75 vsys=27 center=164,123 rscale=3600

See Also

ccdzshift(1NEMO) , ccdmath(1NEMO) , image(5NEMO)

https://github.com/jbjolly/LineStacker
